name: Paris
wikipediaSummary: Paris is a historic city in France, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Claude Monet - Boulevard des Capucines
Gustave Caillebotte - Paris Street, Rainy Day
Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec - At the Moulin Rouge
weirdFacts: There’s an entire underground city of catacombs holding the bones of over six million people.
A law still technically allows taxi drivers to refuse passengers if they have dogs.
The Eiffel Tower was originally meant to be a temporary structure for the 1889 World’s Fair.

name: London
wikipediaSummary: London is a historic city in United Kingdom, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: J. M. W. Turner - The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons
John Constable - The Opening of Waterloo Bridge
weirdFacts: The city technically has two different mayors: one ceremonial and one political.
Crows are kept at a royal fortress because legend says if they leave, the kingdom will fall.
The shortest war in history was declared here, lasting just 38 minutes against Zanzibar.

name: Berlin
wikipediaSummary: Berlin is a historic city in Germany, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: Wild boars freely roam the outskirts and sometimes wander into the suburbs.
A forested hill in the city is built entirely from World War II rubble.
There are more museums than rainy days in an average year.

name: Rome
wikipediaSummary: Rome is a historic city in Italy, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Caravaggio - The Calling of Saint Matthew
Michelangelo - The Creation of Adam
weirdFacts: Cats are legally allowed to live undisturbed among ancient ruins.
There’s a secret keyhole where you can see three countries at once.
One fountain here collects nearly a million euros a year in coins thrown by tourists.

name: Madrid
wikipediaSummary: Madrid is a historic city in Spain, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Francisco Goya - The Third of May 1808
Diego Velázquez - Las Meninas
weirdFacts: It is located in the exact geographic center of the Iberian Peninsula, marked by a plaque in the pavement.
A bear and a strawberry tree are the city’s official symbols and appear on its coat of arms.
The world’s oldest continuously operating restaurant, opened in 1725, is found here.

name: Amsterdam
wikipediaSummary: Amsterdam is a historic city in Netherlands, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Rembrandt - The Night Watch
Johannes Vermeer - View of Delft
Piet Mondrian - View from the Dunes with Beach and Piers, Domburg
weirdFacts: There are more bicycles than residents.
The city has a floating flower market that dates back to the 19th century.
Its houses lean forward intentionally to make it easier to hoist furniture inside through upper windows.

name: Vienna
wikipediaSummary: Vienna is a historic city in Austria, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Gustav Klimt - The Kiss
weirdFacts: The city’s famous Lipizzaner horses perform classical dressage in a baroque palace.
It has coffee houses that have been recognized by UNESCO for their cultural importance.
There’s an amusement park with a Ferris wheel older than most modern nations.

name: Prague
wikipediaSummary: Prague is a historic city in Czech Republic, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Alfons Mucha - The Slav Epic
weirdFacts: An astronomical clock here has been working since the 1400s and still puts on a mechanical show every hour.
A statue of a man hanging by one hand from a pole is often mistaken for a real person.
A crypt beneath one of its churches still contains mummified monks preserved naturally by air currents.

name: Warsaw
wikipediaSummary: Warsaw is a historic city in Poland, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Canaletto (Bernardo Bellotto) - View of Warsaw from the Terrace of the Royal Castle
Jan Matejko - Warsaw Confederation
weirdFacts: The city was almost entirely rebuilt from old paintings and photographs after World War II.
A mermaid holding a sword and shield is its mythical protector.
There’s a neon museum dedicated solely to preserving old Communist-era signs.

name: Stockholm
wikipediaSummary: Stockholm is a historic city in Sweden, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It’s built on 14 islands connected by over 50 bridges.
A subway station network doubles as the world’s longest art gallery.
The city is so clean that people fish for salmon in its central waterways.

name: Oslo
wikipediaSummary: Oslo is a historic city in Norway, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Edvard Munch - The Scream
weirdFacts: The city burns imported rubbish from other countries to generate electricity.
It once knighted a penguin as a member of the royal guard.
A sculpture park displays over 200 naked human figures in dramatic poses.

name: Copenhagen
landmarks: Church of Our Saviour Spiral Tower
wikipediaSummary: Copenhagen is a historic city in Denmark, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Peder Severin Krøyer - Summer Evening on Skagen’s Southern Beach
weirdFacts: The city’s harbor is clean enough for swimming right in the center.
A statue of a mermaid here is one of the most vandalized monuments in the world.
Residents bike so much that there are traffic lights timed specifically for cyclists.

name: Helsinki
wikipediaSummary: Helsinki is a historic city in Finland, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: The city hosts an annual 'Wife Carrying' championship in a nearby region.
There are more saunas than cars in many residential buildings.
Its central train station has statues nicknamed 'the stone men' that are used in advertising campaigns.

name: Brussels
wikipediaSummary: Brussels is a historic city in Belgium, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Pieter Bruegel the Elder - The Tower of Babel
Rogier van der Weyden - The Descent from the Cross
René Magritte - The Son of Man
weirdFacts: Its most famous statue is of a little boy urinating.
It’s home to over 1,000 different types of beer.
A comic book route through the city celebrates characters like Tintin and the Smurfs.

name: Zurich
cuisine: Zürcher Geschnetzeltes (veal in creamy sauce with rösti)
wikipediaSummary: Zurich is a historic city in Switzerland, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It has a law requiring residents to own a bomb shelter or access to one.
The city’s river is so clean that locals swim in it during summer.
A statue of a police officer once had to be removed because pigeons kept perching on his hat.

name: Budapest
wikipediaSummary: Budapest is a historic city in Hungary, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Mihály Munkácsy - The Last Day of a Condemned Man
weirdFacts: The city has more thermal springs than any other capital in the world.
A network of underground caves lies beneath its hills.
It was originally two cities—Buda and Pest—separated by a river and united in 1873.

name: Bucharest
cuisine: Sarmale (cabbage rolls stuffed with meat and rice)
wikipediaSummary: Bucharest is a historic city in Romania, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It has the second-largest administrative building in the world after the Pentagon.
Its nickname was once 'Little Paris' due to French-style architecture and lifestyle.
The city’s underground network includes unused metro stations known as 'ghost stations.'

name: Sofia
wikipediaSummary: Sofia is a historic city in Bulgaria, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: The city sits atop thousands of years of history, with Roman ruins integrated into the metro.
Its mineral springs have been used since antiquity for healing purposes.
A Soviet monument was once repainted by artists to show superheroes instead of soldiers.

name: Zagreb
cuisine: Purica s mlincima (roast turkey with flatbread)
wikipediaSummary: Zagreb is a historic city in Croatia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It has a museum dedicated entirely to failed relationships, the Museum of Broken Relationships.
A cannon is fired daily at noon from a tower in the old town.
Its street lamps were among the last in Europe to be lit by gas and are still hand-lit today.

name: Ljubljana
wikipediaSummary: Ljubljana is a historic city in Slovenia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: A dragon is the symbol of the city, featured on its bridge and coat of arms.
It has one of the world’s oldest philharmonic orchestras, founded in 1701.
Underground caves nearby are inhabited by an unusual creature called the olm, also known as the 'baby dragon.'

name: Bratislava
cuisine: Bryndzové halušky (potato dumplings with sheep cheese and bacon)
wikipediaSummary: Bratislava is a historic city in Slovakia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It is the only capital in the world bordering two independent countries.
The UFO-shaped restaurant on its bridge is a major landmark.
It has a statue of a sewer worker peeking out from a manhole that is a popular tourist attraction.

name: Vilnius
cuisine: Kibinai (pastries filled with meat or vegetables)
wikipediaSummary: Vilnius is a historic city in Lithuania, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: Its old town is one of the largest surviving medieval old towns in Europe.
The city declared a whimsical 'Republic of Užupis' with its own constitution and president.
Hot air balloons often launch directly from the city center.

name: Riga
cuisine: Grey peas with bacon (Pelēkie zirņi ar speķi)
wikipediaSummary: Riga is a historic city in Latvia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It has the largest collection of Art Nouveau architecture in Europe.
Its central market is housed in old Zeppelin hangars.
A local tradition is drinking rye bread kvass, a slightly fermented beverage.

name: Tallinn
wikipediaSummary: Tallinn is a historic city in Estonia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: Its old town is one of the best-preserved medieval city centers in Europe.
It was the first place in the world to hold an online political election.
The city hosts a massive song festival with tens of thousands of participants singing together.

name: Dublin
wikipediaSummary: Dublin is a historic city in Ireland, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: There’s a pub for roughly every 1,000 people.
Its city center was once walled and protected by Vikings.
The city’s river bridges are each uniquely designed, with one resembling a harp—the national symbol.

name: Lisbon
cuisine: Bacalhau à Brás (codfish with eggs and potatoes)
wikipediaSummary: Lisbon is a historic city in Portugal, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It predates Rome, with archaeological evidence of settlement over 3,000 years ago.
It suffered one of the deadliest earthquakes in history in 1755, followed by a tsunami and fires.
Its iconic yellow trams have been in operation since the 19th century.

name: Athens
wikipediaSummary: Athens is a historic city in Greece, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Domenikos Theotokopoulos (El Greco) - View of Toledo
weirdFacts: It’s one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world, over 3,400 years old.
Stray cats are cared for by residents and roam freely among ancient ruins.
There’s a small hill offering a panoramic view that was used in ancient times to announce victories.

name: Nicosia
wikipediaSummary: Nicosia is a historic city in Cyprus, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It is the only divided capital city in the world, split by a UN buffer zone.
The walls surrounding the old town are shaped like a star from above.
It has been continuously inhabited for over 4,000 years.

name: Valletta
wikipediaSummary: Valletta is a historic city in Malta, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It was built almost entirely by the Knights of St. John after the Great Siege of 1565.
The city has over 300 monuments in a very compact area, making it an open-air museum.
Its streets were designed in a grid to let sea breezes cool the city.

name: Luxembourg
cuisine: Judd mat Gaardebounen (smoked pork with broad beans)
wikipediaSummary: Luxembourg is a historic city in Luxembourg, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: The old city fortifications were so strong that the city was nicknamed the 'Gibraltar of the North.'
It is one of the few capitals where the monarch’s palace is right in the center of town and open to the public at times.
The city operates a fully free public transport system.

name: Monaco
cuisine: Barbajuan (stuffed pastry with chard and ricotta)
wikipediaSummary: Monaco is a historic city in Monaco, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Claude Monet - Monte Carlo Viewed from Cap Martin
weirdFacts: It is smaller than New York’s Central Park yet remains a sovereign nation.
Its famous casino once banned citizens of the country from gambling there.
Formula 1 cars race through its regular city streets during the Grand Prix.

name: San Marino
cuisine: Torta Tre Monti (layered wafer cake with chocolate and hazelnut cream)
Passatelli (breadcrumbs, egg, and cheese pasta in broth)
Nidi di rondine (baked pasta rolls with cheese and ham)
wikipediaSummary: San Marino is a historic city in San Marino, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It claims to be the world’s oldest surviving republic, founded in 301 AD.
Its guards still wear colorful Renaissance-style uniforms.
The Three Towers on its mountain are featured on its national flag and coat of arms.

name: Vatican City
cuisine: Fettuccine Alfredo (Italian pasta from Rome area)
Saltimbocca alla Romana (veal with prosciutto and sage)
wikipediaSummary: Vatican City is a historic city in Vatican City, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Raphael - The School of Athens
Michelangelo - The Last Judgment
weirdFacts: It is the smallest independent state in the world by area and population.
It has its own postal service, often faster than Italy’s.
The official ATM machines here offer Latin as a language option.

name: Andorra la Vella
cuisine: Escudella i carn d’olla (meat and vegetable stew)
Trinxat (cabbage and potato dish with pork)
wikipediaSummary: Andorra la Vella is a historic city in Andorra, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: This country has no airports or train stations; you can only reach it by road from Spain or France.
Its parliament, the General Council, was founded in 1419, making it one of the oldest in Europe.
It has more tourists annually than permanent residents, by a factor of about 25.

name: Liechtenstein
wikipediaSummary: Liechtenstein is a historic city in Liechtenstein, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.

name: Iceland
cuisine: Skyr (thick dairy product similar to yogurt)
wikipediaSummary: Iceland is a historic city in Iceland, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Jóhannes Sveinsson Kjarval - Mount Esja

name: Moscow
wikipediaSummary: Moscow is a historic city in Russia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Wassily Kandinsky - Composition VII
Marc Chagall - Over the Town
weirdFacts: Its metro stations are decorated like palaces with chandeliers and mosaics.
The city has a museum dedicated entirely to vodka.
The Kremlin’s walls contain a secret cat colony cared for by staff.

name: Saint Petersburg
landmarks: Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood
wikipediaSummary: Saint Petersburg is a historic city in Russia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Ilya Repin - Barge Haulers on the Volga
Ivan Shishkin - Morning in a Pine Forest
Kazimir Malevich - Black Square
weirdFacts: It was founded by a czar who wanted a 'window to Europe' on the Baltic Sea.
The city is crisscrossed by canals, earning it the nickname 'Venice of the North.'
During World War II, it endured one of the longest sieges in history, lasting 872 days.

name: Kiev
wikipediaSummary: Kiev is a historic city in Ukraine, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Taras Shevchenko - Dnipro Landscape
weirdFacts: Its cave monastery complex has mummified monks preserved for centuries.
A giant Motherland statue here is taller than the Statue of Liberty.
It claims one of the world’s deepest metro stations, more than 100 meters underground.

name: Minsk
wikipediaSummary: Minsk is a historic city in Belarus, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Marc Chagall - Over Vitebsk
weirdFacts: It was almost entirely rebuilt after being destroyed during World War II.
Wide boulevards and monumental Soviet architecture dominate its center.
It has a large island memorial dedicated to soldiers lost in the Afghanistan war.

name: Chisinau
cuisine: Mămăligă (cornmeal porridge with cheese and sour cream)
wikipediaSummary: Chisinau is a historic city in Moldova, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It was almost completely destroyed in World War II and rebuilt in a Soviet style.
The city has more than 20 lakes, many formed by damming small rivers.
It is one of the greenest capitals in Europe, with large parts covered in parks and vineyards.

name: Tbilisi
wikipediaSummary: Tbilisi is a historic city in Georgia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Niko Pirosmani - Feast of the Kings
weirdFacts: Its name means 'warm place,' referring to the natural hot springs in the area.
Colorful wooden balconies are a hallmark of its traditional architecture.
Legend says it was founded after a king’s falcon fell into a hot spring.

name: Yerevan
wikipediaSummary: Yerevan is a historic city in Armenia, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Martiros Saryan - Mount Ararat
Arshile Gorky - The Liver is the Cock’s Comb
weirdFacts: It is one of the world’s oldest continuously inhabited cities, founded in 782 BC.
The city’s main building stone is pink tuff, giving it the nickname 'The Pink City.'
It has giant stairway complex called the Cascade, adorned with modern art.

name: Baku
cuisine: Plov (saffron rice pilaf with meat and dried fruits)
wikipediaSummary: Baku is a historic city in Azerbaijan, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It lies below sea level, making it the lowest-lying national capital in the world.
Oil wells here have been operating since the 19th century, with some of the earliest commercial drilling in history.
Its Flame Towers are lit with LED screens to resemble flickering fire at night.

name: Ankara
wikipediaSummary: Ankara is a historic city in Turkey, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
weirdFacts: It became the capital in 1923, chosen for its central location rather than historical prominence.
The city is famous for a breed of long-haired goat producing mohair wool.
Ancient Roman baths and a temple dedicated to Augustus still stand here.

name: Istanbul
wikipediaSummary: Istanbul is a historic city in Turkey, known for its rich culture, beautiful architecture, and vibrant local traditions. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Osman Hamdi Bey - The Turtle Trainer
weirdFacts: It’s the only city in the world located on two continents.
Ancient Roman aqueducts still carry water through parts of the city.
Underneath its streets lies a vast cistern supported by hundreds of marble columns.

name: Manchester
wikipediaSummary: Manchester is a major city in northwest England with a rich industrial heritage. It was a driving force of the Industrial Revolution and remains a hub for culture, media, higher education, and music. Known for its architecture, sports, and pioneering role in science and technology, it has evolved into one of the UK’s most dynamic metropolitan centers.
art: L. S. Lowry - Coming from the Mill
Ford Madox Brown - Work
Pierre Adolphe Valette - Albert Square, Manchester
weirdFacts: The world’s first programmable computer was built here in 1948.
The atom was first split in a university lab in this city in 1917.
It was the birthplace of the world’s first professional football league.

name: York
wikipediaSummary: A historic walled city in northern England, rich in Roman, Viking, and medieval heritage. It has been a key religious and political center for centuries, known for its cathedral, preserved streets, and layers of visible history.
art: William Etty - The Sirens and Ulysses
weirdFacts: There are said to be more ghosts per square mile here than anywhere else in Europe.
A pub in the city has a Roman road running directly beneath its cellar.
Its cathedral took over 250 years to complete.

name: Cambridge
wikipediaSummary: A historic university city in eastern England, renowned for its prestigious colleges, architectural beauty, and contributions to science and literature. It has been a center of learning and innovation for over 800 years.
art: Sir Stanley Spencer - The Resurrection, Cookham (studied here)
Quentin Blake - Illustrations for university presses
weirdFacts: A mathematical bridge is held together by bolts, despite a legend claiming it originally wasn’t.
A famous apple tree here inspired the discovery of gravity—though the original was replaced.
Students once floated a car onto a college roof as a prank, where it stayed for weeks.

name: Oxford
wikipediaSummary: A historic university city in southern England, home to one of the world’s oldest and most prestigious universities. It has influenced education, politics, and culture for centuries and features a blend of medieval and modern architecture.
art: J. M. W. Turner - High Street, Oxford
William Holman Hunt - The Light of the World
weirdFacts: An exam tradition requires students to wear carnations of different colors depending on progress.
A local museum is one of the oldest public museums in the world.
The oldest university building dates back to the 11th century and still holds lectures.

name: Bath
wikipediaSummary: A UNESCO World Heritage city in southwest England, founded by the Romans for its natural hot springs. It became a fashionable spa town in the 18th century and remains known for its Georgian architecture and historic baths.
art: Thomas Gainsborough - Portraits created while living in the city
weirdFacts: It’s the only place in the UK where you can bathe in naturally hot mineral water.
A crescent-shaped street here inspired architecture across Europe.
Roman engineers built advanced lead piping that still exists beneath modern streets.

name: Edinburgh
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Scotland, known for its medieval Old Town, elegant Georgian New Town, and a world-famous arts festival. It is a center of culture, education, and history, built on volcanic hills overlooking the sea.
art: Henry Raeburn - The Skating Minister
David Allan - The Origin of Painting
Sir Eduardo Paolozzi - Sculptural works exhibited internationally
weirdFacts: A cannon is fired from the castle every day at 1 PM as a time signal.
An extinct volcano sits right beside the city center and can be climbed in under an hour.
The world’s largest arts festival takes place here every August.

name: Geneva
wikipediaSummary: A global city on the shores of Lake Geneva, known for diplomacy, finance, and humanitarian organizations. It is home to the United Nations’ European headquarters and has a rich cultural and scientific heritage.
art: Jean-Étienne Liotard - The Chocolate Girl
weirdFacts: The world’s tallest water jet shoots 140 meters into the air here.
A broken chair sculpture outside the UN symbolizes opposition to landmines.
The city once tried to ban public clocks to stop workers from being distracted.

name: Nyon
cuisine: Papet vaudois (leek and potato dish with sausage)
wikipediaSummary: A lakeside town in western Switzerland with ancient Roman origins, known for its medieval castle, proximity to Geneva, and scenic views across Lake Geneva. It is a regional center for culture, sports, and festivals.
weirdFacts: Roman ruins lie beneath modern streets and can be viewed in public buildings.
A medieval castle here was used as a prison until the 1970s.
It hosts one of Europe’s largest open-air music festivals every summer.

name: Lausanne
cuisine: Papet vaudois (leeks and potatoes with sausage)
wikipediaSummary: A vibrant city on Lake Geneva known for its hills, views of the Alps, and role as the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee. It blends medieval heritage with a strong modern cultural scene.
art: Félix Vallotton - The Bath. Summer Evening
weirdFacts: The city’s cathedral is guarded each night by a traditional watchman calling the hours.
The entire Olympic movement is headquartered here.
A metro system runs on one of the steepest gradients in Europe.

name: Munich
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Bavaria and a cultural powerhouse in southern Germany, known for its beer halls, Baroque architecture, and the annual Oktoberfest. It is also a center for technology, art, and innovation.
weirdFacts: Beer is officially considered a food product under local law.
The world’s largest museum of science and technology is located here.
A river wave in the city center attracts year-round surfers.

name: Aachen
wikipediaSummary: A historic spa and university city in western Germany near the borders with Belgium and the Netherlands. It was the residence of Charlemagne and the coronation site of German kings for centuries.
art: The Palatine Chapel mosaics (UNESCO World Heritage, Carolingian art)
weirdFacts: Its cathedral houses the remains of a medieval emperor in a golden shrine.
Hot sulfur springs here were used for bathing since Roman times.
A local Christmas biscuit was once used as a form of currency in trade.

name: Nancy
wikipediaSummary: A city in northeastern France known for its elegant 18th-century architecture and role as the heart of the Art Nouveau movement. Its historic center, centered on Place Stanislas, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
art: Émile Gallé - Art Nouveau glass and furniture inspired by local flora and produced in the city
weirdFacts: Its central square was once a royal project linking two rival cities by design.
The local university was relocated here from a city annexed by Germany in 1871.
A giant replica of the Eiffel Tower was once built here entirely out of crystal.

name: Lyon
wikipediaSummary: A historic city in southeastern France at the confluence of the Rhône and Saône rivers, known for its Roman ruins, silk trade, and reputation as the gastronomic capital of France.
art: Tony Garnier - Urban designs and murals inspired by the city’s industrial quarters
weirdFacts: The world’s first cinematographic film was shot here in 1895 by the Lumière brothers.
Many old houses are connected by secret passageways once used by silk workers.
Its residents are nicknamed after a small red hat worn by local revolutionaries.

name: Nice
wikipediaSummary: A Mediterranean city on the French Riviera known for its sunny climate, artistic heritage, and historic role as a retreat for European nobility. It remains a major center for tourism and culture.
art: Henri Matisse - View of Nice
Marc Chagall - Biblical Message paintings (inspired by the region)
weirdFacts: The seafront promenade was originally funded by English expatriates fleeing a cold winter.
An annual carnival has been celebrated here for nearly 700 years.
The beach is made entirely of smooth pebbles, not sand.

name: Toulouse
wikipediaSummary: A vibrant city in southwestern France nicknamed the 'Pink City' for its terracotta buildings. It is a major aerospace hub and cultural center blending southern charm with industrial innovation.
art: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec - Posters depicting Parisian nightlife, from a family rooted in the region
weirdFacts: Many buildings are built from pinkish brick, giving the city its nickname.
The world’s first Concorde aircraft was assembled nearby.
A local museum displays early airplanes in a converted slaughterhouse.

name: Lille
wikipediaSummary: A northern French city with Flemish roots and a strong industrial heritage, now known for its culture, art museums, and as a key transport hub connecting Paris, London, and Brussels by Eurostar.
art: Édouard Pignon - Industrial landscapes reflecting the region’s workers
weirdFacts: An enormous annual flea market attracts over two million visitors each year.
It was once part of Flanders and still shows strong Flemish architectural influences.
Its central train station connects directly to London via the Eurostar in under 90 minutes.

name: Barcelona
wikipediaSummary: A Mediterranean coastal city known for its unique architecture by Antoni Gaudí, rich cultural heritage, and vibrant urban life. It is the capital of Catalonia and a major European destination for art and design.
art: Antoni Gaudí - Sagrada Família
Joan Miró - Dona i Ocell (Woman and Bird)
Pablo Picasso - Las Meninas series (created while living in the city)
weirdFacts: The city once turned down hosting the Eiffel Tower before Paris accepted it.
Its beaches are artificial, created for the 1992 Olympics.
A major street follows the outline of ancient Roman walls.

name: Seville
wikipediaSummary: A historic Andalusian city renowned for its Moorish architecture, flamenco culture, and vibrant festivals. It served as a major port for trade with the Americas during Spain’s colonial era.
art: Diego Velázquez - Old Woman Frying Eggs (the artist was born here)
Bartolomé Esteban Murillo - The Immaculate Conception of Los Venerables
weirdFacts: The cathedral’s bell tower was originally built as a minaret.
An enormous wooden structure downtown is nicknamed 'the mushrooms.'
Orange trees line the streets, though their fruit is too bitter to eat.

name: Bilbao
wikipediaSummary: An industrial and cultural city in northern Spain, known for its modern transformation centered around the Guggenheim Museum. It is the economic heart of the Basque Country and a symbol of successful urban renewal.
art: Frank Gehry - Guggenheim Museum Bilbao (architectural artwork that transformed the city)
weirdFacts: A giant floral puppy sculpture guards the entrance to its iconic museum.
The city’s main football stadium has its own chapel for players and fans.
Local residents speak a language unrelated to any other in Europe.

name: Genoa
wikipediaSummary: A historic port city in northwestern Italy, once a powerful maritime republic and home to a long seafaring tradition. It is known for its medieval old town, Renaissance palaces, and role in global trade and exploration.
art: Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione - Baroque paintings depicting local maritime life
Rubens - Palazzi di Genova architectural drawings commissioned here
weirdFacts: Its old town is a maze of narrow alleys where sunlight barely reaches the ground.
A lighthouse here has guided ships since the 12th century.
A native explorer gave his name to an entire continent across the Atlantic.

name: Pisa
wikipediaSummary: A Tuscan city world-famous for its leaning bell tower and medieval architecture. Once a major maritime republic, it retains impressive monuments from its prosperous past.
art: Giovanni Pisano - Sculptures on the Cathedral façade
Benozzo Gozzoli - Frescoes in the Camposanto Monumentale
weirdFacts: The iconic tower began tilting before construction was even finished.
Its cathedral complex was designed to rival Venice and Genoa’s maritime glory.
Local students once used the tower to measure pendulum motion centuries before modern physics.

name: Verona
wikipediaSummary: A northern Italian city famous for its Roman amphitheatre and association with Shakespeare’s 'Romeo and Juliet.' It combines Roman, medieval, and Renaissance architecture in a UNESCO-listed old town.
art: Paolo Veronese - Feast in the House of Levi (born near the city, depicting Venetian influence)
Altichiero da Zevio - Frescoes in San Zeno and San Giorgio churches
weirdFacts: A 2,000-year-old Roman amphitheatre still hosts opera performances today.
A balcony here is claimed—falsely—to be Juliet’s, yet attracts millions of visitors.
During floods, ancient Roman streets become visible beneath modern ones.

name: Venice
wikipediaSummary: A lagoon city built on more than 100 islands, known for its canals, art, and architecture. It was a powerful maritime republic and remains one of the world’s most iconic and romantic destinations.
art: Canaletto - The Grand Canal and the Church of the Salute
Titian - Assumption of the Virgin (in situ in the Frari Church)
Giovanni Bellini - San Zaccaria Altarpiece
weirdFacts: The city has no roads—only canals and footbridges.
It sinks about 1–2 millimeters every year.
Its glassmakers were once banished to a nearby island to prevent fires.

name: Turin
landmarks: Cathedral of Saint John the Baptist
wikipediaSummary: An elegant northern Italian city known for its Baroque architecture, chocolate, and automobile industry. It served as Italy’s first capital and remains a major center for culture and design.
art: Piero della Francesca - Polyptych of Saint Anthony (influenced local schools)
Carlo Mollino - Avant-garde architectural photography and design from the city
weirdFacts: A linen cloth kept here is believed by some to bear the image of a crucified man.
The first hard chocolate bar in history was invented here.
Its streets form a grid pattern dating back to ancient Roman planning.

name: Bari
wikipediaSummary: A southern Italian port city on the Adriatic Sea known for its historic old town, seaside promenades, and as the resting place of Saint Nicholas. It is a key hub for trade and ferry routes to the Balkans.
weirdFacts: A crypt beneath a basilica holds relics of the saint who inspired Santa Claus.
Local grandmothers still hand-make pasta in the streets of the old town.
Its harbor has operated continuously since ancient Roman times.

name: Salzburg
wikipediaSummary: A baroque Austrian city near the German border, famous as the birthplace of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and for its well-preserved Old Town, a UNESCO World Heritage Site surrounded by alpine scenery.
art: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart - Compositions inspired by his upbringing in the city
weirdFacts: A fortress overlooking the city has never been conquered in over 900 years.
The entire historic center is built from local salt trade wealth.
A famous musical film was shot in many of its gardens and streets.

name: Innsbruck
wikipediaSummary: A Tyrolean city surrounded by the Alps, known for its medieval architecture and as a world-class winter sports destination. It has twice hosted the Winter Olympics and remains a major mountain resort.
art: Michael Pacher - Altar artworks created for Tyrolean churches near the city
weirdFacts: It’s one of the few cities where you can ski in the morning and shop downtown by afternoon.
A 15th-century balcony here is covered in over 2,600 gilded copper tiles.
The Olympic torch has been lit here three separate times for major events.

name: Frankfurt
wikipediaSummary: A global financial hub in central Germany, known for its skyline, trade fairs, and as the birthplace of writer Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. It blends modern skyscrapers with medieval streets and museums along the river.
art: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe - Faust and other works written while living in the city
weirdFacts: Its skyline has earned it the nickname 'Mainhattan' due to its skyscrapers along the river.
An entire museum district lines the southern riverbank, each devoted to a different art or science theme.
The city’s airport is so large it has its own postal code.

name: Hamburg
wikipediaSummary: A major port city in northern Germany with a rich maritime history. It is one of Europe’s largest harbors and a cultural center known for its architecture, canals, and vibrant music scene.
weirdFacts: It has more bridges than Venice and Amsterdam combined.
An enormous model railway attraction spans multiple countries and climates under one roof.
A Beatles residency in a local club helped launch their international career.

name: Split
wikipediaSummary: A coastal city on the Adriatic Sea, built around the ancient palace of the Roman Emperor Diocletian. It is a major cultural and economic center of Dalmatia, known for its mix of Roman, Venetian, and modern influences.
weirdFacts: The historic city core is built inside a Roman emperor’s retirement palace.
Residents once turned palace rooms into homes and shops, preserving them for centuries.
Ancient basements under the palace were used to film scenes for a famous fantasy TV series.

name: Dubrovnik
wikipediaSummary: A UNESCO World Heritage city on the Adriatic coast, famous for its medieval walls, marble streets, and baroque buildings. Once a powerful maritime republic, it is now one of Europe’s most picturesque destinations.
weirdFacts: Its city walls stretch nearly 2 kilometers and were never breached in medieval times.
A 14th-century pharmacy still operates within a monastery in the old town.
During the 1990s siege, locals held concerts inside damaged palaces to boost morale.

name: Zadar
wikipediaSummary: An ancient port city on Croatia’s Dalmatian coast, blending Roman ruins, Venetian architecture, and modern design. It is known for its sunsets and innovative coastal installations that combine art, light, and sound.
art: Ivan Meštrović - Sculptures inspired by Dalmatian heritage
weirdFacts: A modern installation here turns sea waves into musical tones.
It has one of the oldest continuously inhabited Roman forums on the Adriatic.
Its sunsets were famously praised by Alfred Hitchcock as the most beautiful in the world.

name: Antwerp
wikipediaSummary: A major port city in northern Belgium on the River Scheldt, known for its diamond district, vibrant fashion scene, and artistic heritage. It was home to the Baroque painter Peter Paul Rubens and remains one of Europe’s most important trading hubs.
weirdFacts: Legend says the city’s name comes from a giant whose hand was cut off and thrown into the river.
It hosts one of the world’s oldest printing presses, still preserved in its original building.
Its railway station is considered one of the most beautiful in the world, featuring a mix of stone, glass, and iron.

name: Gothenburg
wikipediaSummary: Sweden’s second-largest city and its main west coast port, founded by King Gustavus Adolphus. Known for its maritime heritage, innovative design scene, and strong links to music and technology.
art: Carl Larsson - Gothenburg Harbour
weirdFacts: Its fish market is built like a church, complete with stained glass windows.
A local amusement park attracts more annual visitors than the city’s population.
The city was originally fortified by Dutch engineers, giving it a canal system similar to Amsterdam.

name: Linköping
wikipediaSummary: A university and technology hub in southern Sweden known for its cathedral and aerospace industry. It combines medieval heritage with innovation, housing one of Scandinavia’s leading engineering universities.
art: Mårten Eskil Winge - Thor's Fight with the Giants
weirdFacts: The city’s old quarter has been relocated and rebuilt as an open-air museum.
Aviation exhibits include a full-scale Cold War spy plane recovered from the Baltic Sea.
A massive wooden cathedral spire dominates the skyline and has stood for over 700 years.

name: Norrköping
wikipediaSummary: A riverside city in southeastern Sweden once called the 'Manchester of Sweden' for its textile industry. It has reinvented itself as a cultural and creative hub while preserving its 19th-century industrial architecture.
art: Bror Hjorth - Factory Workers
weirdFacts: The river running through the city powered textile mills for over 300 years.
A disused factory complex now houses art galleries, cafés, and tech startups.
A coastal installation nearby plays music generated by the motion of waves.

name: Gdańsk
wikipediaSummary: A historic Baltic port city in northern Poland known for its colorful merchant houses, shipyards, and maritime heritage. It played a key role in the start of World War II and the Solidarity movement that helped end communist rule in Eastern Europe.
art: Anton Möller - The Allegory of Gdańsk
weirdFacts: A medieval crane on the waterfront was once powered by workers walking inside giant wooden wheels.
The city’s iconic liqueur contains genuine gold flakes.
It was once one of the wealthiest ports in the Hanseatic League.

name: Kraków
wikipediaSummary: One of Europe’s oldest cities and Poland’s former royal capital, known for its medieval Old Town, Renaissance architecture, and deep cultural legacy. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a major intellectual and artistic center.
art: Jan Matejko - Prussian Homage
weirdFacts: A trumpeter plays a broken tune from a church tower every hour to commemorate a 13th-century attack.
A fire-breathing dragon statue guards the entrance to a cave beneath the castle hill.
The main market square is one of the largest medieval squares in Europe.

name: Kaliningrad
wikipediaSummary: An exclave of Russia on the Baltic Sea, located between Poland and Lithuania. Once known as Königsberg, it was a major Prussian and German city before becoming part of the Soviet Union after World War II. It is famed for its amber trade and complex history.
art: Caspar David Friedrich - The Sea of Ice
weirdFacts: It was once home to the philosopher Immanuel Kant, whose tomb still stands beside the cathedral.
An unfinished brutalist tower, nicknamed 'the Monster,' dominates the city skyline.
Large parts of the old city lie buried beneath postwar reconstruction and Soviet-era concrete.

name: Odessa
wikipediaSummary: A major port city on the Black Sea, founded in the late 18th century as part of the Russian Empire. Known for its elegant 19th-century architecture, multicultural history, and distinctive humor, it remains one of Ukraine’s most cosmopolitan cities.
art: Ivan Aivazovsky - The Ninth Wave
weirdFacts: The famous staircase leading to the port was designed to look longer when viewed from below.
A vast network of tunnels beneath the city was carved from limestone used in its construction.
The city’s sense of humor is so renowned it’s celebrated in an annual comedy festival.

name: Lviv
wikipediaSummary: A historic city in western Ukraine known for its baroque architecture, cobbled streets, and vibrant coffeehouse culture. Once part of Poland and the Austro-Hungarian Empire, it has a rich multicultural heritage and a thriving artistic scene.
art: Jan Styka - Panorama of the Battle of Racławice
weirdFacts: The river that once ran through the city now flows entirely underground.
Locals boast of having more cafés per capita than almost any city in Europe.
A popular rooftop bar is themed after secret resistance fighters from wartime legend.

name: Rhodes
wikipediaSummary: A historic island city in the Aegean Sea, once home to the Colossus of Rhodes, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Its walled medieval town, built by the Knights Hospitaller, is among the best preserved in Europe.
art: Colossus of Rhodes - Ancient bronze statue depicting the sun god Helios
weirdFacts: An ancient earthquake toppled one of the Seven Wonders of the World here.
The old town’s streets follow a medieval grid built by crusader knights.
Wild deer still roam near the harbor once guarded by one of the Seven Wonders.

name: Heraklion
wikipediaSummary: The largest city on Crete and gateway to the ancient Minoan civilization. It combines Venetian and Ottoman influences with archaeological treasures from Europe’s earliest palace complex at Knossos.
art: Minoan Fresco - Prince of the Lilies
weirdFacts: The nearby ancient palace once housed Europe’s first known flush toilets.
A myth says the island’s caves once sheltered the Minotaur’s labyrinth.
An old Venetian fortress guards the harbor, still standing after earthquakes and wars.

name: Sparta
wikipediaSummary: An ancient city-state in the Peloponnese, renowned for its militaristic society and discipline. Modern Sparta lies near the ruins of its classical predecessor, surrounded by olive groves and Mount Taygetus.
art: Ancient Greek Sculpture - Leonidas of Sparta
weirdFacts: Ancient citizens were forbidden to use gold or silver money, relying on iron bars instead.
All male citizens underwent harsh military training from the age of seven.
The city’s women were among the few in ancient Greece to own property and exercise publicly.

name: Izmir
wikipediaSummary: A major port city on Turkey’s Aegean coast, historically known as Smyrna. It is one of the country’s most liberal and cosmopolitan centers, blending ancient Greek, Roman, and Ottoman heritage.
art: Jean-Léon Gérôme - The Slave Market, Smyrna
weirdFacts: The city’s name has been changed multiple times across millennia, from Greek to Ottoman to modern Turkish.
A centuries-old bazaar here still follows the same street layout from Roman times.
An ancient castle overlooks the modern skyline, offering views once used for early fire signals.

name: Skopje
wikipediaSummary: The capital and largest city of North Macedonia, located on the Vardar River. It combines Ottoman, Byzantine, and modern influences, and has undergone large-scale reconstruction after a devastating earthquake in 1963.
art: Nikola Martinoski - Mother with Child
weirdFacts: A major earthquake destroyed 80% of the city in 1963, after which it was redesigned by a Japanese architect.
The main square features one of the tallest equestrian statues in Europe.
Locals joke that the city has more statues than people.

name: Tirana
wikipediaSummary: The capital and largest city of Albania, nestled between mountains and the Adriatic Sea. It has transformed from a gray communist-era city into a colorful and vibrant cultural hub.
art: Kolë Idromeno - Motra Tone
weirdFacts: Many drab communist-era buildings have been repainted in bright colors by a former artist-mayor.
The city’s most unusual landmark is a pyramid-shaped structure once dedicated to a dictator.
Underground bunkers built during the Cold War now serve as art galleries and museums.

name: Pristina
wikipediaSummary: The capital and largest city of Kosovo, known for its youthful energy, Ottoman heritage, and post-war renewal. It is a growing cultural and administrative center in the Balkans.
art: Esat Valla - The Butterfly
weirdFacts: The city’s library is famous for its bizarre concrete-and-glass bubble design.
A giant monument reading 'NEWBORN' is repainted each year with a new design.
The nearby bear sanctuary houses animals rescued from private restaurants.

name: Belgrade
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Serbia, located at the confluence of the Danube and Sava rivers. It has a long and turbulent history, combining Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian, and modern influences in its architecture and culture.
art: Paja Jovanović - The Takovo Uprising
weirdFacts: The city has been destroyed and rebuilt more than 40 times throughout history.
An underground network of Roman tunnels still exists beneath the old fortress.
A floating nightclub scene on the rivers operates almost every night of the week.

name: Sarajevo
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, known for its religious and cultural diversity. It hosted the 1984 Winter Olympics and endured a long siege in the 1990s, emerging as a resilient symbol of coexistence.
art: Ismet Mujezinović - The Partisan School
weirdFacts: The event that triggered World War I happened on a bridge in the city center.
The skyline includes mosques, synagogues, and churches all within a few blocks.
Residents maintained an underground tunnel during wartime to bring in food and supplies.

name: Marseille
weirdFacts: The oldest city in France, founded by Greek sailors.
Home to one of France’s oldest ports, continuously active for over 2,600 years.
The port was the main entry point for immigrants to France for over a century.

name: Le Havre
weirdFacts: Completely rebuilt after World War II, earning UNESCO World Heritage status.
The city was designed by a single architect, Auguste Perret.
Home to the largest container port in France.

name: Gibraltar
founded: ancient times; captured by Britain in 1704
weirdFacts: The only place in Europe where wild monkeys live freely.
Has its own international airport with a road crossing the runway.
The territory is only 6.7 square kilometers but has its own currency.

name: Valencia
landmarks: Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias
weirdFacts: Home to the Holy Grail, according to local legend.
The birthplace of paella, originally a peasant dish.
Has a unique festival where giant papier-mâché figures are burned.

name: Granada
weirdFacts: The last Muslim kingdom in Spain fell here in 1492.
Home to one of the most visited monuments in Spain.
The city has a unique tradition of free tapas with every drink.

name: Cologne
weirdFacts: The cathedral took over 600 years to complete.
Home to the world’s oldest perfume brand, created in the 18th century.
The city's carnival is one of the largest street festivals in Europe.

name: Essen
weirdFacts: Home to the world's largest board game festival.
The city was once the coal mining capital of Europe.
Has a UNESCO World Heritage site that was a former coal mine.

name: Doncaster
weirdFacts: Once a major Roman fort.
Its racecourse hosted the first recorded 'St Leger Stakes' horse race in 1776.
The world-famous Mallard steam locomotive, which still holds the speed record for steam trains, was built here in 1938.

name: Sheffield
weirdFacts: Known as the 'Steel City' for pioneering stainless steel and cutlery production.
It has more trees per person than any other city in Europe.
Half the city lies within a national park — the Peak District.

name: Liverpool
weirdFacts: Birthplace of The Beatles, whose legacy still attracts millions of tourists.
Home to two major football clubs with stadiums less than a mile apart.
Its waterfront is a UNESCO World Heritage Site modelled on New York’s skyline.

name: Buxton
weirdFacts: Famous for its natural thermal spring water bottled and sold worldwide.
It is Britain’s highest market town, over 300 meters above sea level.
The Georgian Crescent was inspired by the Royal Crescent in Bath.

name: Cardiff
weirdFacts: The smallest capital city in mainland Europe by area.
Home to one of the world’s oldest record shops, founded in 1894.
Its bay area was once the world’s largest coal-exporting port.

name: Groningen
weirdFacts: The city’s university is older than many European nations, founded in 1614.
Cars are banned from much of the city centre, making it one of the most bicycle-friendly places in the world.
The local accent is so distinctive that it’s nearly unintelligible to some native speakers.

name: Palermo
cuisine: Pasta con le sarde (pasta with sardines)
weirdFacts: A series of underground catacombs beneath the city contains thousands of naturally mummified bodies dressed in their finest clothes.
The local opera house is one of the largest in Europe and appeared in the final scene of The Godfather Part III.
The city has been ruled by Phoenicians, Romans, Arabs, Normans, and Spaniards — all of whom left visible marks on its architecture.

name: Tunis
cuisine: Brik (fried pastry with egg and tuna)
weirdFacts: The city stands near the ruins of ancient Carthage, once Rome’s greatest rival.
Its medina is a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 700 historic monuments packed into narrow alleys.
A 9th-century mosque here still operates as both a religious and educational center — one of the oldest in the Muslim world.

name: Gruyères
weirdFacts: The HR Giger Museum here, designed by the creator of the Alien films’ aesthetic, sits beside a medieval castle.
The town lends its name to one of the country's most famous cheeses, which is still made by traditional methods nearby.
Every summer, local herders parade cows adorned with flowers down from alpine pastures in a centuries-old tradition.

name: Bern
weirdFacts: The city’s name is said to come from a bear, the first animal hunted by its founder — and real bears still live in a riverside enclosure here.
Einstein developed parts of his theory of relativity while working at the local patent office.
Its medieval old town is built on a loop of the River Aare, giving it natural protection on three sides.

name: Basel
weirdFacts: The city sits on the borders of three countries and its tram system even crosses them.
One of Europe’s oldest and largest art fairs began here in the 1970s and still draws collectors from around the world.
A local carnival starts at precisely 4:00 a.m. with all lights turned off, leaving only lanterns and piccolos to guide the crowd.
